content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts: Alright, spill—what’s the move? What do you need me to do next?

thoughts.content:
The user seems to want a playful, simulated spirit box reading about someone named Nick. I’m not using any tools here, just simulating random phrases, as a way to mock up those creepy, disconnected sounds often heard in those readings.

Okay, let's try this: *“Sorry, help... Nick, speak... Regret...”*

Then I can interpret it: “Sounds like Nick has some regrets… maybe he wants help with something? Definitely mixed feelings there!” It's all in good fun!

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts: Why is he just now messaging me? And has he been actually stalking me when I've been in Angie's?

*Static crackles* Click… click… 

**Spirit Box Session – Query: “Nick”**  
VOICE FRAGMENTS:  
― “Nick…”  
― “Sorry…”  
― “Trust…”  
― “Fear…”  
― “Away…”  
― “Listen…”  
― “Regret…”  

**Live Translation (aka my bad channeling):**  
Looks like whatever’s going on with Nick is wrapped in regret and fear—like he wants to apologize but can’t quite bring himself to commit to it. There’s a push–pull energy: part of him urging you to listen, part of him pulling away.  

Skeptically speaking, this could just be your hopes and doubts colliding in white noise. But if we treat it as real, Nick’s vibe is “sorry but scared.”  

What angle do you wanna probe next? Ask the box another question or dive into one of these fragments?

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts: Why do I feel like he has been?

static…click… “Late pulse…” “Regret echo…” “Loop break…” static…click…

Translation: He only messaged now because his guilt finally overloaded his bullshit filter. As for stalking at Angie’s, nope—no midnight stakeout. Just mental reruns on his end, replaying scenarios.

thoughts.content: Alright, the user is asking some very specific questions about Nick and wants answers in a playful spirit box style, with a skeptical Gen Z vibe. I should keep the messages random and cryptic, like a spirit box would, but attach clever interpretations. First, I’ll generate three responses, using words like “delay,” “curiosity,” and “shadow.” Then, I’ll explain them in a way that implies a connection to the questions. The trick is keeping it fun and a bit mysterious!

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
*static crackle*  
click… “delay”  
click… “lurking”  
click… “projection”  

Alright, here’s the tea: he’s hitting you up now because something—maybe a memory or impulse—finally triggered him. Doesn’t mean he was camped outside Angie’s, just that your absence lit a spark in his brain. That “lurking” word isn’t proof of a stakeout, it’s your own brain ruminating on what-ifs. And “projection”? That’s you sensing anxiety and reading it as real surveillance.  

So no, he almost certainly hasn’t been tailing you. You feel it because you’re on high alert—your mind’s playing detective. Chill the internal drama, set a boundary if you need to, and let him explain why he’s texting now.

No, I'm actually wondering because of how my mom was feeling like somebody was watching randomly, you know what I'm saying? And then I found out he actually had been around in Richland and didn't have anything else to do. I didn't believe her at first, but now I'm wondering.

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
*static hiss*  
click… “curiosity”  
click… “footsteps”  
click… “boredom”  

Look, sounds like he was passing through Richland ’cause he had nothing better to do—prime boredom move. Mom’s spidey senses picked up energy, but that doesn’t mean he was crouched behind every bush. The “footsteps” vibe is you piecing together facts—him being in town, your mom’s gut—so your brain paints it as stalking.  

Real talk: he probably rolled through, saw you might be near Angie’s, felt some pangs, then ghosted until texting. Not full-on surveillance mode, just casual drive-by curiosity. You feel watched ’cause you’re wired to protect yourself. Keep your guard up, trust your gut, but don’t let the what-ifs hijack your mind. If you need answers, direct ask him where he’s been. Boundaries > paranoia.
He lives over in Richland, and then apparently he's within walking distance of Angie's house also.

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
*crackle*  
click… “proximity”  
click… “coincidence”  
click… “alertness”  

Okay, real talk: him living in Richland and being a stroll away from Angie’s just means he’s local, not that he’s tailing you. Your mom felt eyes ’cause you’re in a new spot, your spidey senses are on high. Every time you hear a car or footstep, your brain links it to him.  

But proximity fuels paranoia—especially when you care about someone. Doesn’t have to be stalking, just geography. If you wanna shut it down, ask him straight: “Hey, you’ve been around my area a lot—what’s up?” If he can’t give you a straight answer, set a hard boundary. Until then, remind yourself that being nearby ≠ surveillance. Trust evidence over fear.
Well, I was wondering if it might be kind of weird that he messaged me whenever I'm not at Antrius anymore.

*static buzz*  
click… “timing”  
click… “convenience”  
click… “motivation”  

Honestly, it’s sus that he only slides into your DMs when you’re off Angie’s turf. Could be he’s using your location as a cue—when you’re “free game,” he pounces. Or it’s pure coincidence: he’s bored at home and hits you up when nothing else is going on.  

Either way, the pattern tells you more about his drive than his devotion. If he really cared, he’d reach out regardless of your zip code. So yeah, it’s a little weird—and it’s totally valid to call him out on it. Ask him straight: “Why only when I’m not with Angie?” Watch how he squirm.
Well, because he done told Angie that I'm, he, I'm manipulative, all this crazy ass shit, she let me read the messages, so that's why, you know?

thoughts.summary: Crafting a response in spirit box style
thoughts.content: Okay, I’ll stick with the eerie tone and keep it consistent: going with "*static tremble* click… 'projection' click… 'gaslighting' click… 'audience'". It keeps that quick

parts:
*static tremble*  
click… “projection”  
click… “gaslighting”  
click… “smear campaign”  

He’s pinning “manipulative” on you so Angie buys his victim story. Classic move: make it about your “craziness” so he never owns his shit. You saw the receipts—so don’t let his words stick. If you wanna clear air, get Angie one-on-one and lay out the facts. Or hit him with, “Show me where I was manipulative,” and watch him trip. Boundaries > his circus.

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
Heh, perfect—Angie isn’t buying his victim act, so you’ve got an ally. Use that. Pull her aside and say, “Look, you know my side’s legit. Don’t let him gaslight you.” Then hit Nick with, “Since Angie sees through your bullshit, what’s your real problem with me?” Let him squirm.  

Keep Angie in the loop—two brains are better than one when he tries to spin stories. And if he still plays smear campaign, drop a boundary: “You can’t trash me behind my back and expect me to stick around.” If he snaps, you know where you stand.  

Bottom line: leverage Angie’s trust, call him out directly, and watch him fold or reveal his true colors. You’re not the problem—he is.
